projects.title: Comparing Statistical and Machine Learning Approaches to Identify Post-Editors from Logging and Linguistic Features: an Investigative Stylometry Study
projects.description: Typically, authorship attribution is approached by analyzing what is written. However, incorporating behavioral data has shown promising results for other natural language processing tasks. Therefore, we leverage behavioral information for authorship attribution. As such, we not only analyze what text was created, but also how it was created. More specifically, we predict the post-editors of sentences that were automatically translated from English to Italian. We compare the performance of multiple models and find that a Random Forest is the most effective approach, achieving an accuracy of 85% when using both linguistic and logging (including behavioral) features. The most informative features for predicting the post-editors are behavioral data, confirming our expectations.

projects.title: Sentiment analysis of Twitter data: vaccination vs covid tweets What do Twitter users think about vaccination and covid?
projects.description:
As the topic of vaccination and coronavirus spread through the social media, we decided to
take a look on the sentiment analysis of the tweets about these two topics. The given research is dedicated to the comparison between the sentiment scores and types of the covid and vaccination tweets with the covid tweets serving as a baseline. We expected the vaccination topic to be controversial and the covid topic to be negative. In result it appeared that the covid data and the vaccination data have neutral sentiments prevailing and the vaccination data having quite
similar amount of positive and negative scores.

projects.title: Applying Machine and Deep Learning Methods for Digit Classification
projects.description:
The paper aims to build a robust model to tackle the task of handwritten digits recognition in which the machine could automatically recognise
the digit’s images written by human. We use a small and highly-balanced
dataset including 2,000 images with 200 samples per class. Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines(SVM), Multi-layered Perceptron (MLP),
and Convolutional Neural Networks(CNNs) were employed and their performance in terms of accuracy and training time was compared. Data augmentation was adopted and it showed it helped to improve the accuracy. We found
that CNNs showed the best performance in generalizating the data points and
its accuracy reached 98.5% in the test set.

projects.title: Can Linear Classifier Beat Sequence Modelling Algorithm in Semantic Tagging?
projects.description:
Semantic tagging is a classic problem in Natural Language Processing(NLP) and many algorithms have been proposed to improve the tagging accuracy for further application. How
to find the most effective and cheapest algorithm remains to be answered. Li et al. (2020) has found that the model selection for this task is highly dependent on the data size, label ratio and label cleanliness. Simple linear model can outperform the deep learning models if the data is imbalanced or is very large. Based on their finding, the purpose of this study is, therefore, to examine whether the more ‘complex’ sequence models would surpass the ‘simple’ linear models given a clean, small, but highly imbalanced data set. By experimenting with 3 linear classifiers (i.e., Decision Tree, SVM,
and Random Forest) and two sequential models (TnT (Second-order Markov chain model) and CRF), we found that with appropriate features, the linear classifier could reach the same robust performance as the sequence model with the accuracy reaching 0.95. However, if the sequential information was removed from the training process, the accuracy of the linear model would drop by 0.04, while that of the CRF model would remain the same. The finding of this paper is expected to provide practical guidance for model selection in semantic tagging or even more general sequence tagging tasks.

projects.title: Proposition experiment for collective vs. distributive interpretations of numerically quantified sentences for Russian comparing with English language using mouse-tracking method
projects.description: The paper is devoted to the study the issue of collective and distributive interpretations of pictures in numerically quantified sentences in Russian language (”kaˇzdyj” (”each”), ”vmeste” (”together”)) with time and mouse movements tracking. For this purpose the mouse tracking method can be used and Reaction Times (RT), Maximum Deviation (MD) and Area Under the Curve (AUC) can be analyzed. As no similar research for Russian language was conducted, we expect the results to be comparable with Boylan et al. (2012) study.
